Award.AwardTitle: CREST: Connecting Researchers, Educators and Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Connecting Researchers, Educators and Students (CREST) program (http://cbm.msoe.edu/crest) is designed to advance use of physical and computer based models of molecular structures to enhance student learning, introduce students to science research and to determine the impact of these additions to the learning environment. Both the 3-D printed protein models and the accompanying learning materials are produced by teams of students and faculty in consultation with researchers whose work is described in the materials or based on a reading of the appropriate primary literature. This current project is disseminating the CREST approach to other institutions through workshops and web-based materials. The project also adds to the information concerning the learning outcomes evolving from CREST since it focuses on the rigorous assessment of the impact of the program on student learning at three large institutions (UW-Madison, Stony Brook University and Rochester Institute of Technology), while simultaneously testing new paradigms of scalability and dissemination across the nation. A new component of this expansion project involves partnering with the Medical College of Wisconsin to offer training to future faculty in student-centered, active pedagogy.

The intellectual merit of this proposal is that it responds to recent calls to transform undergraduate education so that students actively engage in science discourse and practice and the strength and experience of the leadership team.

The broader impact of this project is the information it is gathering on the importance of physical models and visualization in helping students understand biochemical and molecular processes and their importance in metabolic and pharmaceutical processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CREST (Connecting Researchers, Educators and Students) Project utilizes 3D printed physical models as the focal point for transforming undergraduate science education, with two specific goals. The first is to provide undergraduates meaningful, peripheral participation in the scientific community as a means to improve both their disciplinary practice skills (reading primary literature, critical thinking, science communication) and their confidence in becoming scientists. The second goal is to provide appropriate support to assist undergraduate educators in incorporating current research topics in their courses in a student-centered learning environment and to assess the impact of the materials and methods on student learning.

 

The national expansion of the CREST Project has provided opportunities for researchers, educators and undergraduate students to collaborate in the development and assessment of the impact of physical models and ancillary instructional materials on student learning. This collaboration has allowed undergraduate educators to introduce cutting edge research in their courses, engaging students in the excitement of the process of science, rather than simply memorizing facts. Central to the CREST Project is utilization of 3D printers to build accurate physical models of proteins which are otherwise too small to see. Two-dimensional textbook images don’t adequately portray the dynamic three-dimensional interactions of proteins. Tactile models serve as a shared mental model between novice and expert, facilitating a rich scientific discussion.

 

CREST partners identify a research topic they want to incorporate into their courses. They selected 3-6 undergraduates who explored the topic with them, reading the primary literature and creating a 3D model of a protein involved in the process. The team engaged a local researcher studying the topic to provide background and insights into the research topic. Students also visit the research lab and interact with the lab staff. The models students create are designed to tell a specific “molecular story” of structure/function, and students also develop ancillary materials (computer visualizations, molecular landscapes and other hands-on activities that place the protein in the context of a cellular process) to present the topic to their peers. These materials include scaffolding that novices need to understand the topic – and that experts might overlook if they had designed the materials. A backward design approach is used, and educators become scientific teachers as they assess the impact of the materials on student learning. Teams present their projects at local, regional and national research meetings. 

 

Expansion of the CREST Project from a regional to a national program required development of online training materials for using Jmol to design protein models that can be built using 3D printing technologies. An online template allows educators and students alike to create online Jmol tutorials exploring protein structure and function. Website analytics for the last year of the CREST program indicate that tutorial creation pages were visited nearly 18,000 times, and previously created tutorials were explored over 18,000 times. Access to training and the tutorial creator can be found at: http://cbm.msoe.edu/crest/crestJmolResources.php

 

Communities of practice develop within the CREST Project as undergraduate educators with common goals collaborate to develop and assess the value of instructional materials. The Molecular Visualization Literacy workgroup developed a framework of learning goals and objectives for training novice, amateur and experts in twelve big ideas in molecular visualization of macromolecules, and the group is continuing their efforts to develop assessments and competencies. The Chemistry Card Sorting workgroup developed images and card sorting activities for general, organic and biochemistry courses to assess student understanding of chemical principles. The Science Education Research workgroup discussed ways of measuring the impact of physical models on student learning and benefited from a three-day writing workshop that provided the opportunity to focus on data analysis and manuscript writing away from regular routines (and distractions).

 

After many years of collecting case study and anecdotal evidence of the impact of physical models on student learning, the CREST Project has documented who benefits and how models contribute to student learning. Recent publications address the impact of physical models on student learning of structure-function relationships of macromolecules and demonstrate that models 1) remove the gender gap in understanding structure-function relationships as they pertain to the impact of mutations on protein structure and 2) are more effective than active learning activities alone in overcoming misconceptions related to structure-function in the flow of genetic information from DNA to RNA to protein.

 

The CREST Project has directly transformed the teaching practices of CREST partners, and has indirectly impacted student learning beyond the CREST Project through the creation of Jmol tutorials and the tutorial creator tool. The CREST Project has contributed to the growing body of knowledge of how students learn, and in particular how physical models of macromolecules impact student learning of structure-function relationships. Communities of practice developed through the project continue sustainably beyond the scope of the project.
